title: Catullus 1 and 49 - praise of other writers

content.question:
The following questions refer to this passage:

(A)

Cui dono lepidum novum libellum

arida modo pumice expolitum?

Corneli, tibi: namque tu solebas

meas esse aliquid putare nugas

(5) iam tum, cum ausus es unus Italorum

omne aevum tribus explicare cartis

doctis, Iuppiter, et laboriosis.

Quare habe tibi quidquid hoc libelli

qualecumque; quod, o patrona virgo,

(10) plus uno maneat perenne saeclo.

Catullus 1

(B)

Disertissime Romuli nepotum,

quot sunt quotque fuere, Marce Tulli,

quotque post aliis erunt in annis,

gratias tibi maximas Catullus

(5) agit pessimus omnium poeta,

tanto pessimus omnium poeta,

quanto tu optimus omnium patronus.

Catullus 49

In each of these poems Catullus seems to praise the work of another writer while diminishing the value of his own poetry. The interpretation of each poem depends on whether one believes Catullus to be sincere or ironic. (Irony is a literary device by which one meaning is expressed but another, opposite, meaning is implied.) In a well-organized essay, discuss and defend the interpretation you prefer for each poem.

Refer specifically to the Latin in the poems to support your answer. Do NOT simply summarize what the poems say.

unit.text: 4: Teacher's Choice - Latin Poetry and Vergil's Aeneid, Excerpts from Books 1 and 2

skill.text: 3.A: Develop an interpretation of a Latin text.
